description:
The Babylonian underworld was a dark, dreary realm beneath the earth where all the dead dwelled
                regardless of their deeds in life. A place of dust and darkness, ruled by the fearsome goddess
                Ereshkigal and her consort Nergal, from which no mortal could return. Here the dead existed as
                shadowy echoes, stripped of vitality, clothed in feathers like birds, eating dust and clay.
name: ‚ö∞Ô∏è Babylonian Afterlife

underworld.name: Irkalla or Kur
underworld.equality: All dead go here regardless of deeds

journey.gates: Must remove items at each gate

existence.appearance: Shadowy, clothed in feathers like birds

name: Apsu
description: Also known as üíß Apsu.

The Babylonian creation epic describes how the ordered cosmos emerged from primordial waters through
                divine conflict. Young Marduk defeated the chaos dragon Tiamat, creating heaven and earth from her
                corpse and humanity from her consort's blood. This mythic battle established Marduk's kingship and
                the eternal principle: order must be violently wrested from chaos and constantly defended.
name: üåä Babylonian Creation Myth

worldStructure.heaven: Created from upper half of Tiamat
worldStructure.earth: Created from lower half of Tiamat

description:
In Buddhism, death is not an ending but a transition. The consciousness exits the dying body and
                enters the bardo‚Äîan intermediate state between lives‚Äîwhere it experiences visions based on karma.
                After up to 49 days, the consciousness is drawn to rebirth in one of six realms according to its
                accumulated karma. Only nirvana offers true liberation from this endless cycle.
name: Bardo, Rebirth & Nirvana"

bardo.description: Intermediate state between death and rebirth
stages: Chikhai Bardo (moment of death) - clear light
bardo.text: Bardo Thodol (Tibetan Book of the Dead)

sixRealms.deva: Gods - long life, pleasure, but still in samsara

karma.types: Good karma ‚Üí higher realms; Bad karma ‚Üí lower realms

nirvana.state: Beyond description, not annihilation, not heaven

description:
Buddhism uniquely teaches that there is no creation by a supreme deity. Instead, all phenomena arise
                dependently through an endless chain of causes and conditions. Nothing possesses inherent,
                independent existence. This teaching of Pratityasamutpada (Interdependent Origination) explains
                both the arising of the universe and the perpetuation of suffering in the cycle of rebirth.
name: Interdependent Origination
connections: Rebirth & Liberation - Where dependent origination leads
Buddhist Cosmology - The structure of cyclical existence
The Buddha - Who discovered this truth
Manjushri - Wisdom that sees dependent arising
Jewish Creation (Bereshit) - God creates by divine word
Hindu Creation - Brahma creates from cosmic egg
Greek Creation - Gods emerge from Chaos
Norse Creation - Gods create from giant's body

pratityasamutpada.concept: All phenomena arise from causes and conditions

description: The fundamental Buddhist doctrine that all phenomena arise in dependence upon multiple causes and conditions. Nothing exists independently or permanently. The twelve links explain how suffering and rebirth arise.
name: Buddhist Mythology

philosophicalDetails.meaning: All phenomena arise dependent on causes and conditions

implications.noCreator: No first cause or creator needed

description: The principle that all intentional actions have consequences that determine future conditions. In Buddhism, karma drives the cycle of rebirth (samsara) and can only be transcended through enlightenment.
name: Buddhist Mythology

description: The three poisons or mental afflictions: greed (raga), hatred (dvesha), and delusion (moha). These are the root causes of suffering and bind beings to samsara.
name: Buddhist Mythology

description: The ultimate goal of Buddhist practice, the state of liberation from suffering, desire, and the cycle of rebirth. Literally means "extinguishing" - the extinction of greed, hatred, and delusion.
name: Buddhist Mythology

notions.negative: End of suffering, end of rebirth

types.nirupadhishesa: Without remainder - at death of enlightened one

mahayana.bodhisattva: Delay final nirvana to help others
mahayana.sunyata: Emptiness - nirvana and samsara not different

description: The sacred abode of Avalokiteshvara and historic residence of the Dalai Lama in Lhasa, Tibet. Named after Mount Potalaka, the mythical abode of Avalokiteshvara.
name: Buddhist Mythology

description: The six realms of existence (Sanskrit: gati or bhava) are the destinations for rebirth in Buddhist cosmology, depicted in the Bhavachakra (Wheel of Becoming). These realms are driven by karma‚Äîthe consequences of intentional actions‚Äîand the three root poisons: greed, hatred, and ignorance.
name: Buddhist Cosmology
Buddhist Mythology

description:
Christian teaching describes the soul's journey from physical death through judgment to eternal
                destination - Heaven (communion with God), Purgatory (purification), or Hell (separation from God).
                This journey culminates in bodily resurrection and final judgment at Christ's return.
name: Christian Mythology

Gehenna - Place of purification and punishment

description:
The Genesis creation narrative reveals God speaking the universe into existence through His word,
                bringing order from chaos, culminating in humanity made in the divine image. A six-day work followed
                by sacred rest, establishing the pattern for all creation.
name: Christian Mythology

Tzimtzum - Kabbalistic divine contraction for creation
Sefirot - Divine emanations in creation process
Shabbat - The sacred seventh day of rest

description: Grace (from Latin gratia, Greek charis) is the fundamental principle of God's dealings with humanity in Christian theology. It represents God's free and unmerited favor‚ÄîHis kindness toward those who deserve punishment, His love toward those who are unlovely, His mercy toward those who are guilty. Grace is not something God owes to humanity; it flows from His own character as a loving, compassionate, and merciful God.
name: Christian Cosmology

Rachamim - Divine compassion and mercy
Teshuvah - Repentance enabling return to God
Yom Kippur - Day of Atonement and forgiveness

Pleroma - Return to divine fullness
Hindu Prasada - Divine grace and blessing
Buddhist Karuna - Universal compassion

description: The incarnation (from Latin incarnatio, "to make flesh") is the Christian doctrine that God the Son, the second person of the Trinity, took on human nature and became a human being in Jesus Christ. This is expressed in the profound declaration of the Gospel of John: "The Word became flesh and dwelt among us."
name: Christian Cosmology

Shekinah - Divine presence dwelling among humanity
Immanuel - "God with us" from Isaiah's prophecy

description: The resurrection of Jesus Christ is the cornerstone of Christian faith. Three days after His crucifixion and burial, Jesus rose bodily from the dead, conquering death and vindicating His claims to be the Son of God. The tomb was found empty, the grave clothes left behind, and Jesus appeared alive to numerous witnesses over forty days‚Äîto Mary Magdalene, to the disciples, to more than five hundred people at once.
name: Christian Cosmology

Valley of Dry Bones - Ezekiel 37 vision

description: Christian theology teaches that all humanity stands in need of salvation because of sin. Since the fall of Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden, humanity has been separated from God by sin, which the Bible describes as both inherited guilt (original sin) and personal transgressions. Sin results in spiritual death and separation from God's presence, making salvation necessary for restoration.
name: Christian Cosmology

Kippur - Day of Atonement traditions

name: Creation & Origins

name: Death & the Afterlife
description: Death & the Afterlife is a figure from celtic mythology.

The ancient Egyptians developed the most elaborate afterlife beliefs in human history. Death was not an ending
                but a transformation‚Äîa dangerous journey through the Duat (underworld) requiring preparation, knowledge, magical
                protection, and moral worthiness. Those who succeeded became eternal spirits dwelling in paradise. Those who
                failed faced oblivion.
name: The Journey to Paradise

journey.death: Soul separates into Ka (life force) and Ba (personality)
journey.burial: Book of the Dead, amulets, provisions
journey.duat: Navigate 12 hours of night through underworld

judgment.weighing: Heart weighed against feather of Ma'at

outcome.justified: Become Akh (blessed spirit), dwell in Field of Reeds
outcome.condemned: Heart devoured by Ammit, cease to exist

description:
Egyptian creation mythology is not a single narrative but multiple accounts from different theological centers,
                each emphasizing different aspects of how order emerged from chaos. These myths share common themes: the
                primordial waters, self-creation, divine speech/thought, and the establishment of Ma'at (cosmic order).
name: From Nun to the Ennead

memphite.creator: Ptah
memphite.theology: Ptah creates through his heart and tongue

name: Egyptian Cosmology
description: Also known as üåÖ Egyptian Creation Myths.

The Duat is the Egyptian underworld, a realm of darkness, danger, and transformation that must be traversed
                each night by Ra in his solar barque and by the souls of the deceased seeking eternal life. The journey through
                the Duat's twelve hours represents the sun's passage from west (death/sunset) to east (rebirth/dawn), mirroring
                the soul's journey from death to resurrection.
name: Egyptian Underworld Journey

realmDetails.description: The Egyptian underworld through which the sun god Ra travels nightly and souls of the dead must navigate

structure.hours: 12 hours of night, each with challenges

name: Nine Gods of Creation
description: Also known as ‚ú® The Ennead (Nine Gods of Heliopolis).

name: Egyptian Cosmology
description: Also known as üåä Nun (Primordial Waters).

When mortals die in Greek mythology, their psyche (soul/shade) descends to the Underworld ruled by Hades
                and Persephone. The journey involves crossing treacherous rivers, facing judgment, and eternal residence
                in one of several realms based on one's life. Unlike many traditions, most souls face neither eternal bliss
                nor torment, but rather a dim existence in the Asphodel Meadows.
name: The Journey to Hades

elysium.also: Elysian Fields, Islands of the Blessed

asphodel.experience: Dim, shadowy existence - neither joy nor torment

tartarus.depth: As far below Hades as heaven is above earth

description:
The Greek creation myth describes reality's emergence from primordial Chaos through successive generations
                of divine beings. From the void came fundamental forces, from forces came Titans, from Titans came Olympians.
                Each generation overthrew the last, establishing new cosmic order through violence and will.
name: From Chaos to Cosmos
Mount
description: Also known as ‚õ∞Ô∏è Mount Olympus.

name: Greek Mythology
description: Also known as üåå Primordial Deities.

name: Greek Mythology
description: Also known as üåç The Titans.

Beneath the earth lies the vast, shadowy kingdom of Hades‚Äîthe inevitable destination for all mortal souls.
                Neither heaven nor hell in the Christian sense, it is a realm of shades where the dead exist in various states:
                from the blessed paradise of Elysium to the endless twilight of Asphodel to the torments of Tartarus.
layers: Cape Taenarum (Southern Greece): A cave-shrine to Poseidon said to descend directly to Hades. Heracles used this entrance to capture Cerberus.
Lake Avernus (Italy): A volcanic crater lake whose poisonous vapors killed birds flying overhead, marking it as a gateway to death.
River Acheron (Epirus): The river of woe, where souls gathered before crossing into Hades proper.
Caves of Eleusis: Connected to the mysteries of Demeter and Persephone, involving descent symbolism.
Tantalus: Stands in water that recedes when he tries to drink, beneath fruit trees whose branches rise when he reaches‚Äîeternal hunger and thirst for serving his son to the gods.
Sisyphus: Pushes a boulder up a mountain, only for it to roll back down forever‚Äîpunishment for cheating death twice.
Ixion: Bound to a flaming wheel that spins forever through the sky for attempting to seduce Hera.
The Danaids: Forty-nine daughters of Danaus who murdered their husbands on their wedding night; they eternally carry water in sieves to fill a leaking bath.
Tityos: A giant whose liver is eternally eaten by vultures (regenerating daily) for attempting to rape Leto.
The Titans: Kronos and his followers, imprisoned after Zeus's victory, suffer in the deepest darkness.
Thanatos: Personification of death itself, twin brother of Hypnos (Sleep). He escorts souls to Hades.
Charon: The grim ferryman who transports souls across the rivers Styx and Acheron for the price of an obol.
Cerberus: The three-headed guard dog who prevents souls from escaping.
The Erinyes (Furies): Alecto, Megaera, and Tisiphone‚Äîancient goddesses who pursue those guilty of blood crimes, especially kinslaying.
Hecate: Goddess of crossroads, magic, and the liminal spaces between life and death. She aided Demeter in finding Persephone.
Hypnos: God of sleep, dwelling in a dark cave in the Underworld, twin of Thanatos.
Death is Final: Once dead, souls cannot return to life (with extremely rare exceptions granted by the gods).
No Eating: Living visitors must not eat Underworld food or they cannot return. Persephone ate six pomegranate seeds, binding her to spend six months yearly in Hades.
Proper Burial Required: Without proper funeral rites and the obol for Charon, souls cannot enter Hades but wander the banks of Cocytus for a hundred years.
Don't Look Back: When granted permission to leave (as Orpheus was), one must not look back at the Underworld or the deal is broken.
Respect the Dead: Shades must receive periodic libations and offerings from the living. Neglected dead become restless and vengeful.
Divine Permission Needed: Only with the gods' blessing can living mortals descend and return (katabasis)‚Äîan extremely rare occurrence.
name: The Greek

rivers.styx: River of hatred - boundary, oath river

description:
In Hindu cosmology, death is not an ending but a transition. The eternal soul (Atman) migrates through
                countless lifetimes, driven by karma, until achieving moksha - liberation from the cycle itself and
                union with the divine. This is the journey every soul undertakes through the vast expanse of time.
name: World Mythos Explorer

temporary.duration: Finite stay based on karma balance

rebirth.castes: Can be born in different stations
rebirth.forms: Can be human, animal, divine, etc.

liberation.result: Union with Brahman, end of rebirth

description:
Hindu creation is not a single event but an eternal cycle. The universe emerges from the cosmic
                waters, flourishes for billions of years, then dissolves back into the unmanifest, only to be
                reborn again. Creation, preservation, and destruction dance in endless rhythm.
name: World Mythos Explorer

cosmicEgg.brahma: Emerges from lotus from Vishnu's navel

purushaHymn.concept: Universe created from cosmic being Purusha
purushaHymn.sacrifice: Gods sacrifice Purusha to create world

name: Hindu Cosmology

The cosmic ocean of milk that was churned by gods and demons to obtain the nectar of immortality (amrita). Vishnu rests on the serpent Shesha floating on this ocean.
name: Hindu Cosmology
Redirecting...

Islamic eschatology presents a comprehensive journey of the soul: from the moment of death through
                Barzakh (the intermediate realm), resurrection on the Day of Judgment, the crossing of the Sirat bridge,
                and finally eternal dwelling in Jannah (Paradise) or Jahannam (Hell) based on faith and deeds.
name: Islamic Cosmology

death.questioning: Munkar and Nakir question in grave
death.barzakh: Intermediate realm until Day of Judgment

judgment.book: Book of deeds given (right hand = saved, left = damned)
judgment.bridge: Sirat bridge over hell - sharp as sword

jahannam.duration: Eternal for unbelievers, temporary for sinful Muslims (debated)

description:
Islamic cosmology describes how Allah created the heavens and earth through His command "Kun!" (Be!).
                In six distinct periods or "days," all of existence came into being from absolute nothingness,
                culminating in the creation of humanity as khalifa (steward) of the Earth.
name: Islamic Cosmology

displayName: Asgard - Realm of the Aesir Gods
description: Asgard (Old Norse: √Åsgar√∞r, "enclosure of the √Üsir") is the celestial realm of the Aesir gods in Norse mythology. It sits at the top of Yggdrasil, the World Tree, and is one of the Nine Realms that make up the Norse cosmos. Unlike the Christian concept of Heaven as an eternal paradise, Asgard is a fortress‚Äîa place of strength and preparation for the final battle of Ragnarok.
name: Norse Cosmology
From Ginnungagap to the First Humans
description: Also known as üåå Norse Creation Myth.

stages: Ymir (first giant) emerges from melting ice

description: Ragnarok (Old Norse: Ragnar√∂k or Ragnar√∏kkr) is the prophesied end of the cosmos in Norse mythology‚Äîa series of catastrophic events culminating in a great battle that will result in the deaths of numerous gods, the destruction of the Nine Realms, and the submersion of the world in water. Yet from this destruction, a new world will arise, purified and renewed.
name: Norse Cosmology

description: Yggdrasil (Old Norse: Yggdrasill) is the enormous ash tree that stands at the center of the Norse cosmos, connecting all Nine Realms. The tree is not merely large‚Äîit is described as stretching across all of existence, with branches that reach into the heavens and roots that delve into the deepest underworld. It is both the physical and spiritual axis mundi (center of the world) around which all cosmic activity revolves.
name: Norse Cosmology

realmDetails.description: The World Tree, cosmic ash connecting all nine realms

layers: Styx (River of Hatred): The sacred boundary river; gods swear unbreakable oaths on the Styx
Acheron (River of Woe): River of pain and suffering, sometimes considered the main river crossed

name: Roman Mythology
description: Also known as üíÄ Roman Afterlife.

name: Roman Mythology
description: Also known as üåÖ Roman Creation Myth.

The Sumerian view of the afterlife is stark and sobering. Unlike Egyptian paradise or Greek rewards,
                Kur (the underworld) offers no hope for joy or reward. All humans‚Äîrighteous and wicked, rich and
                poor, king and slave‚Äîdescend to the same dark realm where they exist as shadows, eating dust and
                drinking clay water. Death is the great equalizer, and the afterlife is not about judgment or
                redemption but simply the continuation of diminished existence. Only proper burial and regular
                offerings from living descendants provide any comfort.
name: ‚ö∞Ô∏è The Sumerian Afterlife

description: Also known as ‚ö° The Anunnaki.
name: ‚ö° The Anunnaki

description:
Sumerian creation mythology describes the emergence of order from the primordial sea and the
                establishment of cosmic structure through divine action. Unlike creation ex nihilo (from nothing),
                Sumerian creation is the organization of pre-existing chaotic matter. The gods themselves emerge
                from nature, then shape it. Humanity is created not as beloved children but as laborers to serve
                the gods and maintain the cosmic order.
name: From Nammu to Humanity
Me (Divine Powers)
description: Also known as ‚ú® Me - Divine Powers.

philosophicalDetails.definition: Divine powers, decrees, fundamental attributes of civilization

description:
If the Lightning Flash describes the soul's descent into matter, the Serpent Path (or Path of Return)
                describes its ascent back to source. This is the Great Work (Magnum Opus) of Hermetic alchemy‚Äî
                transforming the base metal of ordinary consciousness into the gold of enlightened awareness.
                Through study, practice, and initiation, consciousness climbs the Tree of Life from material
                awareness (Malkuth) to divine union (Keter).
name: The Hermetic Path of Return

description:
In Hermetic cosmology, creation is not a single event but an ongoing process of divine emanation‚Äî
                infinite light progressively condensing into finite form. The Lightning Flash traces the path of
                divine energy as it descends through the ten Sefirot of the Tree of Life, from pure unity (Keter)
                to material manifestation (Malkuth). This is the "descent into matter," the divine becoming world.
name: The Lightning Flash of Emanation
Hermetic Cosmology
description: Also known as üå≥ The Tree of Life.
